title: The WHERE Clause
learning_objectives: Combine conditions with AND, OR, and NOT
Use LIKE for pattern matching with wildcards
Handle NULL values correctly with IS NULL / IS NOT NULL

definition.concept_explanation: The WHERE clause filters query results by specifying conditions that rows must meet.

common_mistakes.title: Using = instead of IN for multiple values
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: The = operator only compares to a single value. For multiple values, use IN.
common_mistakes.fix_sql: SELECT * FROM users WHERE city IN ('Seattle', 'Portland');
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Use IN for multiple possible values

common_mistakes.title: String comparison without quotes
common_mistakes.error_sql: SELECT * FROM users WHERE city = Seattle;
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: Without quotes, SQL treats Seattle as a column name instead of a string value.
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Always use quotes around string literals

practice_challenge.description: Find all users whose email ends with '@email.com' and are under 30.
practice_challenge.hint: Use LIKE for pattern matching with the % wildcard.
practice_challenge.solution: SELECT * FROM users WHERE email LIKE '%@email.com' AND age < 30;
practice_challenge.explanation: LIKE '%@email.com' matches any string ending with '@email.com'. The AND operator ensures both conditions are met.
